items.message: River levels are stable or falling. Areas most at risk include low lying areas in Tetbury, Badminton, Brook End at Luckington, Corsham, Lacock and the road at Reybridge Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Bristol Avon, Tetbury Avon, Sherston Avon, Dauntsey Brook, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around low lying areas in Tetbury, Badminton, Brook End at Luckington, Corsham, Lacock and the road at Reybridge. Further rain as forecast for Tuesday afternoon and for the rest of the week.  River levels are expected to rise in response to this rain. We are closely monitoring the situation . Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water . Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 12:00PM on 21 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message: High river levels today, 20th January 2026, may lead to flooding. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads around Church Laneham to Rampton Road. No significant rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. River levels at Torksey Gauge will remain high until the 21/01/2026. We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 10am on 21/01/26 or as the situation changes.

The risk of flooding remains. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads around Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road and Sileby Mill road, and farmlands at Cossington, Sileby, Barrow, Quorndon and Cotes. Light rain is forecast over the next 24 hours. River levels remain high at the Pillings Lock Gauge and will continue to be so over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water & avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 09:00AM on 21 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Bank Road alongside the River Nene, east of Peterborough and west of Dog-in-a-Doublet Sluice
items.message: High river levels since the 16th January are expected to cause flooding and further rainfall showers are forecast over the next several days, and therefore river levels will remain high. During periods of high tide the River Nene will be unable to discharge into the sea, resulting in tide lock conditions. This is likely to lead to localised flooding of the North Bank Road, between Peterborough and Rings End. Whilst this Flood Warning is in force, the Local Authority will close North Bank Road. Diversionary routes will be put in place and further updates will be available through local media. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. Refer to local authority website for road closures. This message will be updated by 12pm on 21st January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message:
High river levels today may lead to flooding.  Flooding is possible on 20 January 2026.  This information is correct as of 15:30 on Tuesday 20 January. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 32 centimetres of water on the road. The causeway at Welney has approximately 25 centimetres of water on the road.  Due to the uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. The Environment Agency are liaising with Norfolk Highways, who will decide whether to close the road. For more information about the causeway at Welney, please visit the 'Welney Flood Watch' Facebook group. Please note that the content of this group does not represent the views of the Environment Agency. There are currently no issues on Earith causeway.

The weather forecast is improving, and we expect levels to start returning to normal soon.  We are monitoring rainfall and river levels.  Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.  This message will be updated by 10:00 on Wednesday 21  January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.message:
River levels remain high on the Chertsey Bourne.

Flooding is expected this evening and overnight on 20 January 2026.

Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected, especially in the Free Prae Road area. A band of rain is forecast to move over the area this evening and overnight, 20 January 2026. We expect river levels to begin rising overnight in response to the rainfall.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. We are clearing blockages from debris screens. 

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Go to River levels online for updates on current river levels.

This message will be updated by 10:00 21 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. 
Weather conditions are expected to improve and no further flooding is expected.   
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.   
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.

items.message:
Forecast rising river levels this evening may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 20 January 2026 . 
Flooding is possible in locations near the Upper Dorset Stour, Shreen Water tributaries between Gillingham and Sturminster Newton. Locations most affected will be low lying land and roads near rivers. Further rainfall is expected this evening and overnight tonight, which could cause river levels to rise. Flooding is possible. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have and avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 3:00PM on 21 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

This is a Flood Alert Update. River levels are high at the Stinsford river gauge as a result of the ground being saturated and the recent rainfall. Flooding could still affect locations near the Lower Dorset Frome tributaries between Dorchester and Wareham, with low lying land and roads near rivers expected to be most affected. There is further heavy rainfall expected this evening and overnight tonight 20 January 2026 which may cause rivers to rise. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk, cycle or drive through flood water. People in this area should continue to monitor local water levels and weather conditions. This message will be updated by 2:00PM on 21 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

High river levels on Wednesday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 21 January 2026 as rainfall is forecast Tuesday night and on Wednesday. 
Minimal impacts are expected Tuesday night, but if as much rain falls as predicted, from 10:00 21/01/2026 minor flooding could affect riverside properties on Forewood Lane and near Crowhurst Recreation Ground. From 14:00 21/01/2026 Bexhill Road Recreation Ground, and gardens that back onto the rec (near the Combe Haven) could be affected. River levels could peak a little higher than 15/01/2026. More rain is forecast Thursday and Friday. River levels and flood risk should initially begin to reduce by 23:00 21/01/2026 in Crowhurst. In Bulverhythe river levels could remain high until the weekend. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have . Install flood protection products in Crowhurst. 
This message will be updated by 4:00PM on 21 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
River levels remain high on the Rivers Yeo and Parrett.
Low lying land and roads are expected to be most affected by flooding. Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if the drain level at Huish Episcopi pumping station exceeds 7.3 m.
For the latest river and drain levels refer to https://check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels.
River levels are high and the Parrett Relief Channel is running. Pumping has been inhibited by the high river levels but will commence today as levels and tides allow. A band of moderate to heavy rain is forecast from this afternoon (Tuesday), with further rainfall tomorrow. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 21 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

Overtopping is forecast from the Glastonbury Millstream and the River Brue at North Drain and Westhay.  The River Brue is forecast to be bankfull upstream of Bruton Dam with field flooding likely.

From 15:00 21/01/2026 flooding could affect Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road, Hellingly. From 22:00 21/01/2026 flooding could affect North Street, River Lane, The Old Clergy House, Deans Place Hotel, Alfriston. Possibly similar impacts to 15/01/2026. More rain is forecast Thursday and Friday. River levels and flood risk should begin to reduce by 06:00 22/01/2026 in Hellingly, and 14:00 22/01/2026 in Alfriston, but could be high until Saturday. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Don't put yourself or others at risk . Avoid roads that flood (Mill Ln Church Rd Hellingly, North St Alfriston).

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Asker, River Brit, River Bride, River Char, River Lim

items.message:
High river levels overnight may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 20 January 2026 . 
Locations most affected will be low lying land and roads near rivers. River levels are forecast to rise at the Charmouth river gauge, following the recent rainfall. Flooding could affect all rivers in the West Dorset area with low lying land expected to be most affected. Flooding is possible near the Rivers Lim, Char, Winniford, Simene, Brit, Asker, Mangerton and Bride.  Further heavy rainfall this evening and overnight night tonight could lead to flooding. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water  
This message will be updated by 4:31PM on 20 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

High tides on Wednesday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible for 2 hours either side of Wednesday's morning and afternoon tides at 00:45 and 13:00 on 21/01/2026. 
The weather increases tide table values by 0.25 m. Total forecast tide is 5.92 metres Chart Datum at 00:45 and 5.98 at 13:00 (2.87 and 2.93 mAOD) at Littlehampton. Strong South Westerly Force 5 wind. The condition of the shingle beach was affected by Storm Goretti in early January 2026. Waves could cause overtopping of the beach, affecting Climping Street Car Park. A small amount of water may then flow or be directed westwards along Mill Lane towards residential property in Climping Street. Thursday's tide at 01:15 22/01/2026 is forecast to be higher (3.00 mAOD), but with smaller waves. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . We routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have . Access could be restricted. Take care if visiting Climping beach. 
This message will be updated by 4:00PM on 21 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council

items.message:
High tides, strong winds and large waves this evening may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from 7:30PM on 20 January 2026 onwards. 
Areas most at risk include Preston Beach, Swanage, Poole Harbour and Christchurch Harbour. Tides over the next few days are expected to be high. The detailed tidal forecast for the next 2 tides is or the first peak level at Weymouth of 1.39 mAODN at 7:30PM on 20/01/2026, with Southerly force 5 winds. (mAODN is height above average sea level.) The second tide at Weymouth will peak at 1.77 mAODN at 9:00AM on 21/01/2026, with Southerly force 7 winds. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of high tide times. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Avoid coastal roads, footpaths and carparks, which may be flooded . 
This message will be updated by 3:00PM on 21 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

High tides and forecast weather conditions over the next two days may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from 19:45 to 21:30 on 20/01/2026 and 07:00 to 9:45 on 21/01/2026. 
Locations most affected will be low lying land and roads near rivers or on the coast. 

Around Bridlington Lifeboat Station in particular, overtopping may be seen due to large waves and strong winds. 
We are closely monitoring the situation .

items.message:

Areas particularly at risk include exposed coastal areas of Plymouth Sound including Cawsand, Kingsand and The Hoe, The high tide at Plymouth on Wednesday is at 7:13am and 7:36pm, times of high water will vary along the coast. Forecast total high tide level is 2.79mAOD and 2.67mAOD respectively. Expect tide levels along the coast to be over 0.5m above tide table level. STRONG force 7 South Easterly winds and offshore wave heights of over 2.7m are forecast over the high tide. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Avoid coastal roads, footpaths and carparks, which may be flooded . 
This message will be updated by 4:30PM on 21 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers in the Forest of Dean
items.message:
Forecast rising river levels overnight may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from the morning of 21 January 2026 . 
Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Gloucester to Chepstow. Other locations that may be affected include Westbury and Lydney. 
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels  
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses . 
This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 21 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

Rising river levels this evening may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from overnight on 21 January 2026 . 
The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is currently 7.36m. Water will enter Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway if this level exceeds 7.45m. The drain level at Currymoor pumping station is 4.19m. Cutts Road floods when this level is above 5.75m, and New Road when the level is above 6.18m. Please refer to the Somerset Council website for information on road closures in the area. Further rain, possibly heavy, is forecast for tomorrow morning and water levels are likely to remain high. 
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels . 
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water . Avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 5:00PM on 21 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

Forecast rising river levels this evening may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 20 January 2026 . 
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Nadder, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around the River Nadder and tributaries between Donhead St Mary and Salisbury. Further rainfall is expected this evening and overnight tonight, which could cause river levels to rise. Flooding is possible. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have and avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 3:00PM on 21 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high and steady. Flooding is possible today, 20 January 2026. Flooding may affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to the Bourne Brook. We are closely monitoring the situation. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
This message will be updated by 11:00AM on 21 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

High tides on Wednesday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible for 1 hour either side of Wednesday afternoon's tide at 12:34 on 21/01/2026. 
The weather increases tide table values by 0.5 m. Total forecast tide is 4.72 metres Chart Datum (2.13 mAOD) at Cowes. Strong South Easterly Force 6 wind. Large waves will cause spray overtopping and overwashing of defences across the exposed coast at Yarmouth, Freshwater Bay, Sandown, Shanklin, Gurnard and Ryde. This will flood esplanades, sea front car parks and roads in these locations. As Cowes is sheltered from waves, impacts, if any, will be minimal. We do not expect property flooding. Thursday's tide at 00:49 22/01/2026 is forecast to be 11 cm lower (2.02 mAOD). 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have . 
This message will be updated by 8:00AM on 21 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

The risk of flooding remains. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Willington, Barrow upon Trent, Swarkestone, Bargate Lane and the access roads to Willington Meadows, the Twyford Village access road, Church Lane at Barrow, and Ingleby Lane. Rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours. River levels at Willington and Shardlow Gauge are likely to remain elevated until 24/01/26. We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 9am on 21/01/26 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the West of Dorset
items.message: Groundwater levels continue to be high and rising, and may lead to flooding. Flooding is possible in the West Dorset area. Groundwater levels are rising in response to the recent rainfall. Levels may continue to rise and flooding of fields and roads is possible. Further rainfall is expected over the next few days which may see levels continue to rise. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding. We are closely monitoring the situation . Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. This message will be updated by 4:00PM on 26 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

Near gale force 7 winds, in a southerly direction, and offshore wave heights of over 2m are forecast over the high tide. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Avoid beaches and coastal promenades, which may be flooded .

Strong Force 7 southerly winds and offshore wave heights of over 2.0m are forecast over the high tide. 
	 
We are closely monitoring the situation and closing flood gates. 
	 
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water . 
	 
This message will be updated by 3:00PM on 21 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Cranborne Chase area
items.message:
High groundwater levels may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from 19th January 2026 onwards. 
Groundwater levels have risen in response to recent rainfall. Levels are expected to continue to rise and flooding of fields and roads is possible. Levels are reactive to further rainfall. Flooding of roads and fields is possible. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding. Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed . 
This message will be updated by 1:00PM on 26 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. We are clearing blockages from debris screens.

High river levels on Wednesday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 21 January 2026 as rainfall is forecast Tuesday night and on Wednesday. 
Only minimal impacts are expected Tuesday night, but if as much rain falls as predicted, from 10:00 21/01/2026 minor flooding could affect property at Slaughter Bridge on the Coolham road, as well as isolated farm buildings, fields and rural roads between Coolham and Henfield. It is possible water may approach gardens of Church Close, Shipley. River levels could peak similar to 15/01/2026. Further periods of rain are forecast Thursday and Friday. River levels and flood risk should initially begin to reduce in Coolham by 06:00 22/01/2026, but may be higher than normal until Saturday. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Don't put yourself or others at risk . Avoid roads that flood, including Slaughter Bridge, Coolham Road. 
This message will be updated by 4:00PM on 21 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

Rising groundwater levels are expected to cause flooding. 
Flooding is expected from 19th January 2026 onwards. 
Groundwater levels in Cranborne Chase remain high. Areas that could be affected include: Iwerne Minster. The groundwater level at the Iwerne Hill Farm borehole has risen to 109.77m, and is expected to remain high. Further bands of rain are forecast over the next few days. Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. Residents may experience inundation of septic tanks and sewer systems. Properties may experience flooding in cellars in affected areas. Flooding of roads is expected, please take care when driving. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
If you have a pump, make sure it is working and switched on. Think about alternative power sources in case of power cuts Please do not drive through floodwater as this may cause bow waves. 
This message will be updated by 2:00PM on 26 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

High tides, strong winds and large waves are expected to cause flooding tomorrow morning. 
Flooding is expected from 8:45AM on 21 January 2026. 
Areas most at risk include areas in close proximity to Christchurch Harbour including Mudeford, Stanpit, the Quomps and Wick area. The detailed tidal forecast for those who use it, is for the peak level at Christchurch Harbour of 1.60mAODN at 10:45AM on 21 January 2026, with Southerly force 7 winds. (mAODN is height above average sea level.) Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of high tide. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water . Avoid beaches, coastal roads, footpaths and carparks which may be flooded 
This message will be updated by 3:00PM on 21 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Minor Watercourses from Heighington to Dunston
items.message: River levels remain high following recent rainfall. Flooding is possible on 20th January 2026. Locations most affected will be low lying land and roads near rivers. Our forecasts indicate that flooding to properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are closely monitoring the situation. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Avoid low lying roads, near rivers which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 12pm on 21st January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Great Ouse from Thornborough to Newport Pagnell
items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. 
Weather conditions are expected to improve and no further flooding is expected.   
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.   
Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals. Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.

items.description: River Great Ouse from Newport Pagnell to Sharnbrook
items.message: High river levels today may lead to flooding.  Flooding is possible on 20 January 2026.  Areas most at risk are around the River Great Ouse from Newport Pagnell to Sharnbrook. The weather forecast is improving, and we expect levels to start returning to normal soon.  We are monitoring rainfall and river levels.  Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.  This message will be updated by 10:00 on Wednesday 21 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and Parrett, Upper Reaches

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Yeo, River Parrett, River Cary

items.message:
Forecast rising river levels this evening may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from the evening of 20 January 2026 . 
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Yeo, River Parrett, River Cary, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around the Ilchester to Yeovilton road at the end of runway. Further rain, possibly heavy, is forecast for tomorrow and we expect rivers to respond. 
We are closely monitoring the situation and clearing blockages from debris screens. 
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water . Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. 
This message will be updated by 5:00PM on 21 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and Parrett, Yeovilton to Huish Episcopi
items.message:
Forecast rising river levels this evening may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from the evening of 20 January 2026 . 
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Yeo, River Parrett , with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around the A37 south and A303 south west of Ilchester. The Ilchester to Limington road and road to Ilchester Meads. There is also a risk of flooding at Hainbury Mill, Ilchester. Water reaches bottom of ringbanks at Ilchester Meads and Ilchester. Further rain, possibly heavy, is forecast for tomorrow and we expect rivers to respond. 
We are closely monitoring the situation and clearing blockages from debris screens. 
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water . Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the South Winterbourne Valley
items.message:
Rising groundwater levels are expected to cause flooding. 
Flooding is expected from 19th January 2026 onwards. 
Groundwater levels in West Dorset remain high. Areas that could be affected include: Winterbourne Abbas, Winterbourne Steepleton, Martinstown, Winterbourne Monkton, Winterbourne Herringston and Winterbourne Came. The groundwater level at the Kingston Russell borehole has risen to 116.56m, and is expected to rise further over the next few days. Residents may experience inundation of septic tanks and sewer systems. Properties may experience flooding in cellars in affected areas. Flooding of roads is expected. Roads may be damaged by floodwater. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
If you have a pump, make sure it is working and switched on. Think about alternative power sources in case of power cuts . 
This message will be updated by 2:00PM on 26 January 2026 or as the situation changes.
